channel.title: Aviation
channel.description:
I'm studying and planning to go as an airplane mechanic. Trying to figure out what "the length of the hydrocarbon chains found in the fuel" means. Also need to name some of the hydrocarbon molecules found in the fuel.
dunno if this would fall into homework category. Maybe it does, since it's studying.
Anyways, anyone have a clue of what I'm talking about?
P.S, any troll comments will personally get hunted down and buttfudgeed by a rhinoceros horn. You have been warned.
but srsly, i ned halp
P.P.S only post if you have an idea or maybe a link that I may find this information at.
P.P.P.S wikipedia doesn't help answer these questions D:

item.title: Aviation
item.dc:creator: @goudont goudont
item.description:
@goudont wrote:

Bowser jr:

Kerosene and naphtha are both molecules. (Why am I stating the obvious?)

I didn’t finish reading, JUST got to it when you posted lmfao. thanks for the help, man!

Read full topic

item.title: Aviation
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“goudont, post:5, topic:548345”][quote author=Bowser jr link=topic=667252.msg4462188#msg4462188 date=1418085357]

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jet_fuel

Please state at all time which airliner you work for so I can’t avoid it.

I’ve been on that page for about 45 minutes now haha. I’m talking about aviation fuel in general, either kerosene, or naphtha. gotta find the chemistry side of it. any idea what I mean?

Kerosene and Naphtha are hydrocarbons. The length of them is clearly stated on the wikipage.
[/quote]

wow how did I miss that? and how about some of the molecules? I’ve just recently started the studying, so I don’t have much clue of the chemical side, I wasn’t so good at chemistry D:[/quote]
Kerosene and naphtha are both molecules too. (Why am I stating the obvious?)

Read full topic

wow how did I miss that? and how about some of the molecules? I’ve just recently started the studying, so I don’t have much clue of the chemical side.

*Edit: I’ve got it, thanks
